filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-three pencil drawings produced by Blake during his first decade as an independent artist, 1779-1790. Drawing lies at the core of Blake's life as an artist. Pencil was his preferred medium for sketching—more flexible, less expensive, and more easily corrected than pen and ink or chalk. Preliminary work with the pencil preceded more finished work, either as separate sketches for prints and paintings or as drawings underlying water colors. Blake's nineteenth-century writings on the arts testify to his conviction that drawing was fundamental to all pictorial expression: "The distinction that is made in modern times between a Painting and a Drawing proceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing" (*A Descriptive Catalogue*, Erdman page 549); "Let a Man who has made a Drawing go on & on & he will produce a Picture or Painting but if he chooses to leave off before he has spoild it he will Do a Better Thing[.]" (*Public Address*, Erdman page 576); "Painting is Drawing on Canvas & Engraving is Drawing on Copper & Nothing Else…& he who Draws best must be the best Artist…." (*Public Address*, Erdman page 582); "Dear Sir, excuse my enthusiasm or rather madness, for I am really drunk with intellectual vision whenever I take a pencil or graver into my hand…." (letter to William Hayley, 1804, Erdman page 757).
Blake no doubt executed a great many more pencil drawings than those extant today. Sketches were not intended for exhibition or sale; most were probably discarded, while others may have been retained only because of more developed compositions on the other side of the leaves. Even the slightest and least aesthetically ambitious drawings offer insights into the origins and earliest realizations of Blake’s designs. These first thoughts on paper often tell us more about Blake’s habits of mind, when joined by eye and hand, than more finished works. Sketches are “the first fruits of [Blake’s] imagination,” as Geoffrey Keynes states in the introduction to his *Pencil Drawings of William Blake* (1927).
The forty-three pencil drawings presented here, produced in Blake’s first decade as an independent artist, show his early debt to academic standards of precise copying and to the neoclassical emphasis on outline. The first four works may have been drawn while Blake was a student in the Royal Academy schools. Other sketches are preliminaries for some of Blake’s most important designs. Among these are the *Study for “Glad Day”, or “Albion Rose”* (Object 6), Blake’s iconic vision of the human form divine in energetic pose, and three sketches (Objects 34-36) for illustrations to *Tiriel*, the only group of finished drawings Blake composed for one of his own poems. Several sketches are early efforts at picturing events in the Bible, Blake’s main inspiration for designs throughout his life. This biblical cluster includes *The Resurrection of the Dead* (Object 10), *Samuel Presenting Saul to the People* (Object 15), and *Job’s Wife and Other Sketches* (Object 31). Other studies, such as *Ugolino in Prison* and its verso (Objects 21-22), reveal the beginnings of subjects also of lifelong interest for Blake. Only a few drawings for Blake’s illuminated books have survived, but studies such as *Sketches for “The Book of Thel”* and *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure* (Objects 37-39) offer fascinating glimpses into Blake’s methods of graphic production and revision.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.note: Possibly the *Sketch for Thomas Commins's "An Elegy"* (the recto design) with the dealer Robson and Co. in 1913 (see Butlin 98, then untraced); private collection; sold Christie's, 17 Nov. 1992, lot 18 (£7150 to Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, New York); sold Christie's, 7 Nov. 1995, lot 73 (£4025 to the dealer Thomas Agnew & Sons acting for Robert N. Essick).

objnote.p: These sketches, not discovered until 1993 and thus not in Butlin, are alternative designs for Blake's engraving in Thomas Commins, *An Elegy Set to Music*, dated 1786 in the imprint on Blake's engraving. These sketches are on the verso of a monochrome wash drawing also for the Commins engraving. Another pair of recto/verso drawings, both in monochrome wash, for this engraving is in the Essick collection; these drawings are also titled *Alternative Designs for Commins's Elegy* (not in Butlin because not discovered until 1992).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several separate scenes are visible in this drawing. Lower left, a short-haired figure seated in a boat bends both arms to hold oars. He(?) faces left but turns his head to look right, perhaps toward the figures standing on the land at right. The frontmost of these two standing figures appears to face away from the viewer. He(?) wears a gown and possibly a hood. The figure in back may face left; one arm, extended downward, and hand are visible. An unidentifiable motif of some sort is sketched below these figures. Against the right edge of the drawing, a third figure, who may be bearded, appears to lean forward and to the left (perhaps over some sort of horizontal barrier?) with both arms extended downward. A smaller version of a similar figure appears below. An oval form in the upper left corner contains a separate scene drawn upside down that depicts three figures. When viewing the scene right side up, a single figure at left stands facing right with both arms raised horizontally beside what appears to be a boat. There may be a tree with leafy foliage behind this figure at left. He(?) may reach and stride toward the pair of figures standing or walking across from him at right facing left. The shorter figure, who may be a child, raises its right arm at 135 degrees; the taller figure wears a gown and may be female. These two figures appear to stand on an area of ground of a shore, but it is unclear whether the single figure also stands on the ground or partially in the water depicted in the foreground. This scene is likely related to Blake's 1786 engraving for Commins's *An Elegy Set to Music* which has a similar oval composition and figural arrangement. The other vignettes in the drawing probably also relate to this project.

component.illusobjdesc: Lower left, a short-haired figure seated in a boat bends both arms to hold oars, which he(?) may row. This figure may have a beard. Both legs are bent at the knees. He faces left but turns his head to look right, perhaps toward the figure standing on the land at right.

The figure in the lower left corner of the drawing sits in a long, narrow boat. The oars held by the figure, along with the vessel's size, suggest it is a rowboat. There may be additional objects inside the boat behind the figure, but the significance of these is indeterminate.

Two figures stand in the center of the composition. The frontmost figure wears a gown and perhaps a hood. He(?) appears to be facing away from the viewer. An unidentifiable motif of some sort is sketched below this figure.

Two figures stand in the center of the composition. The figure in back of the other appears to face to the left and extends one arm and hand downward. His(?) fingers are slightly spread with palm held out, perhaps in a gesture toward the figure seated in the boat at left.
The outline of a cloud appears to the left of the hand of one of the two standing figures.

Against the right edge of the drawing, a third figure, who may be bearded and thus male, appears to bend forward and to the left (perhaps over some sort of horizontal barrier?). Both arms are extended downward with his hands making fists. Most of his body faces to the right, but his head and shoulders are turned forward.

A figure appears in the lower right portion of the leaf. He(?) is a smaller version of the figure above. He bends over to the left and extends his arms downward. His hands may be in a fist and he may hold some object dangling below his hands.

An oval form in the upper left corner contains a separate scene drawn upside down that depicts three figures. When viewing the scene right side up, a single male(?) figure at left stands facing right with both arms raised horizontally. He may bend forward or reach toward the pair of figures across from him at right. The figure appears to wear a garment, perhaps a shirt or gown, that extends outward from his body at right, as if lifted by the wind. He may be striding rapidly to the right or leaping over the water.

In the oval scene upper left, the figure at left stands beside what may be a small boat (perhaps a canoe or rowboat) that appears to float on the body of water visible in the lower foreground of the scene. The figures to the right may stand on the shore of the body of water.
There may be a tree with leafy foliage behind the figure standing at left in the oval scene top left.

Across from the single standing figure at left, a pair of figures who face left stand or walk near the right side of the oval scene. The shorter figure, who may be a child, raises its right arm at 135 degrees. This figure may wear a hat and perhaps pants.

Across from the single standing figure at left, a pair of figures who face left stand or walk near the right side of the oval scene. The taller figure has the slight suggestion of long hair, indicating she may be female, and appears to wear a gown.
